Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2011 12:13PM starbeauty wrote: Kathleen - my rad onc asked if I was having these symptoms and a whole list of others - every week I was getting rads... I agree with Dlb823 - call your rad onc.
Posts.Title: Chest heaviness side effect of radiation? kathleen1966 starbeauty

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2011 06:49AM starbeauty wrote: Jenn - I was a hospice nurse... the answer to your question about the level of "loopy" is yes - your body will acclimate to the pain medications and you will be able to function well - not constantly sleeping.  It takes about 1 week.  Unless your rad MD or onc MD do something to strike the cause of the pain - you will continue to need these meds - and will probably need them in increasing doses.  Be careful to remain well hydrated and don't skip meals.  You are in my prayers today.
Posts.Title: Will it get better? jenn3 Bruburn

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2011 03:03PM starbeauty wrote: geo... it has been about 14 months since my surgery... and my chest is still "tight".  I find myself reaching up to touch it in the evening because it feels weird... some discomfort, but mostly weird.  Under my arm when the skin touches the other skin - it feels like after you go to the dentist - all numb.  I check it all the time because I am worried about LE and when it feels really puffy - usually it is. Then I try to position my arm to drain - try to move the fluid manually - sometimes in the middle of my work day.   I stretch it every night when I work out.  I stretch it when I shower.  When I had radiation - it was the worst - I could hardly lay the arm in the position they wanted because it felt like it was going to rip.  I have/had cording - where I feel the pulling all the way into my hand.  I try to just rub that out during the day when it shows up.  Sometimes I get two little pouches of pain at my elbow you can actually see bunching up under my skin... who knows why it does that.   Is it better - yes - but I know it is there all day every day.  I don't have very much numbness - so a lot of nerve endings are tingling or itching or twitching.  You will find a new normal and some hours will go by when you are too busy to notice the aggravants.  The immediate incision pain and drain pain will disappear within 6-10 weeks - but your own special brand of MX leftovers will remain.   Perhaps some of the members that have been out there longer than me can encourage us both that much more fades as time goes by...  gentle hugs to you geo...
Posts.Title: how did you feel after MX geocachelinda sespebadger

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2011 04:01PM starbeauty wrote: Bedo... I was burned badly during rads.  Huge area from abdomen to mid-neck, to shoulder, through body to a 6x4 inch patch on my back of burn.  Peeling... blistering... etc.  Burn color is still there 1 year later.  My arm also began to tighten up with each new rad treatment so that when they positioned it - it caused stabbing pain.  I took Advil... it hardly touched it.  I took Vicodan... it worked.

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 12:54PM starbeauty wrote: This is my first post. I have been a "thread stalker" for awhile... just want to say that my grandmother has had BC x3, my mother BC x2 (double MX) and now me X1 at age 48... here is the good news - my grandmother is 96 and still with us... by mother is 72 and still with us... and 1 year post surgery, chemo, rads and tamox - I'm still here too. Faithful... be true to your name - faithful each day to walk in courage and joy - and someday your grandchild, like me, will find hope in your story.  Gentle hugs to all of you for your courage and compassionate posts... I have needed to read them almost daily to make it through this year.
Posts.Title: Never hearing the word Cured!!!! faithfulheart jennifer1

Posts.Content: May 4, 2011 07:52AM starbeauty wrote: Txkari...It is such a uniquely personal decision... Connected to all kinds of issues. My DH loved my breasts... They were pretty. So...when hit withBC I elected to keep one breast for as long as I can. the other one I was told I could do lump. But I was worried they wouldn't get the margins. I went for the MX. It was a good choice... The nasty stuff went right to the chest wall. If I turn on my side... DH just sees the remaining breast when we are intimate. Not that I hide the scars and missing breast, but sometimes it just needs to disappear for my sanity. I am monitoring it like a hawk. MRI and mammo and exams by everyone and their brothers... Do what is bests for you... Do what gives you what you need... Then don't look back or second guess yourself. FYI...I don't regret my choice,but I don't like being lopsided with one double D and nothing on the other side. Hugs to you...
Posts.Title: Unilateral or Bilateral txkari cinnamonsmiles

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2011 07:11PM starbeauty wrote: Yorkie... The word from my MDs was that my RO was very good... Don't really know... Just know the experience was different than everyone described. I was in there about 30-40 minutes with multiple precision placements. I ended up with a 5x3 patch coming out my back... Who knows what my lung looks like now... And the burn went half way up my neck, out to my shoulder and down to my tummy.
Posts.Title: "Easy" part of treatment? MY A**! BlueCowgirl Tazzy

Posts.Content: May 21, 2011 05:04AM starbeauty wrote: moving forward... So glad you are almost done with the initial onslaught of medical treatment!!! I hit a wall after it was all done... I was depressed, filled with anxiety, sooooo exhausted, and emotional. the initial doses of Tamox may have caused some of it, but the transition was the other problem. what helped... Hate... Hate... Hate exercise,but it is working!!! I feel better and have maintained my weight on Tamox...just do about one hour per day of strength, bike and tread, but it really helps. Recently, found a thread on here of girls getting together in our area. One is from my town... Talking-to her helps me to let it go... Hear total understanding... And feel like at least one person on this planet that can give me real responses. Going to church lifts my spirit. Talking on this site helps me work through my issues and worries too.
Posts.Title: Tips for Transitioning from Active Treatment Moving_forward Moving_forward

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2011 03:12AM starbeauty wrote: I have often felt worried and been concerned about the money being spent on me - it seems outrageous - but when you put this same thought up on this thread... I thought why not her... there is only one "her" in the universe.  Why shouldn't we do everything possible to give her another day to touch those around her, light the world up with her smile, share her wisdom, bless her community, encourage others hurting... this is the wonder of our country - that indeed you are valued - and worth every penny we are spending.  You helped me today... thank you... I am glad you are here.

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2011 02:27PM starbeauty wrote: ((topless))... I have/am in the same struggle... But here is the argument I have given me... My brain was washed at birth with female hormones and has been ingrained with a lifetime of it... My hands are tiny compared to my husband, my face is feminine, my shape is womanly, my voice is female... My legs are nothing like my husband's... There are other parts of me that seduce and cause excitement in him. I wish I could put my breast back... I hate how I look there, but despite my obvious lack of cleavage he is still turned on by me, and so that intimate moment is mine to lose... I have already drawn his attention... But my sad victim face is an instant turn off... So it is my responsibility to accept that my female arsenal is merely down a weapon... I still have full control of the action! :)

Still have scars and burn marks almost 2 years later. Was so exhausted and depressed. nearly did me in... Didn't go to the last 3 boosts... Called and said I didn't care I was done. Radiation was worse for me than taxol, the red devil, and surgery.

Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 06:25PM starbeauty wrote: Disney - They told me radiation was strongly recommended as well... because of 3 nodes - I could have gone either way - but they said that it was possible they would fail me at the "local" level if I didn't do the radiation.  So... again I did it.  I burned me so badly that I really can't have a reconstruction - the area so vast that burned - even burned on my back.  It concerns me what else burned under my skin.
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2011 11:19PM starbeauty wrote: Had adjuvant dd taxol every two weeks. SEs were rough but I worked through it all. Lost all eyelashes eyebrows etc with taxol... Tremendous amount of fatigue and joint and muscle pain... Had initial neuropathy with the last dose with all fingers... It faded about 2 weeks later. Super amount of lasting exhaustion and depression 6 months out from last dose. Took awhile to recover... But I was functional the entire time.
Posts.Title: Taxol Regimen Question! youngmommy youngmommy

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 09:30PM starbeauty wrote: Intwoplaces...Sorry for the delay... had to run out... when I say bad - I needed a medication painted onto me several times a day to reduce the temperature of the burn.  I happened in the last week - and a declined the last 3 boost days because I simply couldn't stand the pain.  The burn stretched from mid-neck to my tummy - skin came off in multiple places, but mostly from under my arm.  Up until the last two weeks I was doing fine - then it just darkened and burned. I was told I was in the 1% - and that the majority of everyone else does well - not sure what happened. So mostly on these boards you will see everyone making it through with little or no problems - sometimes you will see emotional problems and fatigue and I had that incredibly toward the end and for about 8 weeks afterward.  The skin now just looks tan - but the PS said the blood vessels are destroyed for such an extensive area and she doesn't want to mess with it at all.  I wish you well - know that we understand and talk to us if you need support... I felt very vunerable and found myself truly dealing with the loss while I was going through radiation - and that grief and sense of loss added the whole experience.  I think I was just beginning to grasp what NED really meant as well... and when I began to realize I wasn't going to ever feel "free" of BC... that also was floating around the room on that table with me.  The positive... I made it out the other side of all that... I truly am beginning to find peace and a sense of purpose again - and I am beginning to feel pretty and femine again... vs. a burned, battered, bald thing.  You can do it - just go one day at a time and talk to everyone here... they will talk you through.
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2011 12:09PM starbeauty wrote: I echo many of the experiences described... I guess what demoralized me the most is not being able to find or have them find anything to cover the deep hallow across my chest... Nothing to wear to bed that I could feel sexy in... And seeing the look of pity and horror at what I look like under my clothes. I cried all the way home...felt so sorry for myself... Ranted I would never feel like I was a real woman ever again... Had a royal meltdown. I am not going back to either place I tried. The foob weighs 2 lbs. I weighed it. I hate it. I have 4 mega bras I don't wear. I am using my old Bali bras too. Otter... There were covers I have three of them that the second store clerk gave me... Your clerk was so full of it. I am going to try one more place this year after the holidays... If they can't help me I will have to learn to help myself. I don't feel confident ordering without trying it on, but by the time you total up the gas and time to these stores... I could have taken a chance on online and sent it back for less.

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2011 08:58AM starbeauty wrote: Ginger - who cares what the staff think - it is their job to put up with our emotions too.  We are a whole person - not just a piece of meat to radiate... and as that whole person they need to support our emotional needs too.  What you did - you did.  Move forward knowing you have done the majority of the treatments - and you are almost done with it.  Hang in there Ginger... and let your inner voice lead you.  Warm hugs for your day...
Posts.Title: Radiation and Emotions sheuber MexicoHeather

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2011 06:41PM starbeauty wrote: Countrywoman - NED=no evidence of disease.  We aren't cured with the current medical treatment plans.. so NED is the prognosis we receive if we are blessed to dance with NED once all this treatment is over.  Not sure about your HER2 with Taxol question... someone will come along to answer that one... but the Neulasta is to ensure that your immune system does not become so compromised that you fall victim to an opportunistic infection and/or that the blood levels are so concerning that they are forced to withhold treatments from you.  It makes you hurt - but it does its job.
Posts.Title: Is my game plan too much???? countrywoman starbeauty

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2012 01:23PM - edited Jan 1, 2012 01:24PM by starbeauty Hi Justjudi... Yes.. I work in a nursing program located in a career and tech high school... In fact 4 different high schools. I worked all the way through dose dense ACT... With the help of Neulasta and Emend. I basically washed my hands non stop... Touched as few surfaces as possible... Took supplements... Did NOT touch my own face except to do makeup and wash. off on chemo infusion days only..did 6 weeks of rads after that... Missed nothing despite burns that caused skin to slough off... It can be done... Not easy...awful hard, but possible.
Posts.Title: Working while doing chemo ? JustJudi talbrig13

Posts.Content: May 6, 2011 12:57PM starbeauty wrote: ...not sure there is any comparison you can draw, but after ACT and Now on Tamoxifen...it has taken an entire year for the WBC to come up even close to normal... You may simply need more time. if you had neulasta it may have stabilized you initially,but now it is all your own system...
Posts.Title: WBC count low 6 mo after chemo sanbar8771 revkat

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2011 05:27PM starbeauty wrote: Hi 3girls... I took off right after surgery 4weeks... But other nurses on this board went back after 3 weeks. I wasnt really healed well by then. Started chemo after i went back to work and had the port put in the final week before going back. Then worked through a similar tx plan full time... Went back to school this fall plus worked full time. Trying to finish my MS. It can be done... Exhausting but possible... Hang in there...and try to do what someone told me... Only deal with a week at a time... Don't get too far ahead in your head... Just do what you need to do this week...
